document.title: Early Childhood Standards of Quality for Birth to Kindergarten

F45F0EBB32484285B8727BA2350B5083.description: Put their own belongings away without prompting, most of the time.

19C728A297C44303B3CE177A70D32FCC.description: Offer help to peers when they notice someone is struggling with an activity.

AD8AA2B2C4F243159A07695FE8C257BA.description:
Care for the environment with increasing responsibility and skill (e.g.,
cleaning up, wiping the table, flushing the toilet, helping others).

D6AA398263D74AAB9E9DA98021631E99.description:
Continue to follow expectations or boundaries set in varying situations, most
of the time.

64C0A0052271404AB6B2720152A49F21.description:
Participate in a group discussion to decide on expectations for the learning
environment and offer detailed suggestions.

3F7CA871E1224949B15D8CEE3D00ED33.description: Put their own belongings away with prompting.

0CD64FBE4C5E49A2A155A95B9F996C59.description:
Show increasing comfort in taking on different roles in their environment
(e.g., helping others, turning off the water, holding the door).

CEAABEA848764EE69AA9093FBF7075AB.description: Follow expectations or boundaries set in varying situations, most of the time.

A8E95C1549854C0B90D2C65313695709.description:
Repeat the language of a particular expectation when they see another child
acting outside that boundary.

4D0F09A0EB4A4044B5A2FA9BA4BD030F.description:
Participate in a group discussion to decide on expectations in the learning
environment.

8D042AA7290148CE95255E6AC252E4B4.description:
Engage with their day-to-day routines with increasing levels of interest,
participation, and responsibility, such as taking on the role of “gardener” to
water the plants or offering their opinion on which of two story choices they
should read as a group.

341E0806D75345D0810C5382DBB482FB.description:
Express spontaneous affection–running up to give a hug, for example–to the
people with whom they spend a lot of time.

47645C499BA24776B25310088A588ADE.description:
Show a desire to positively participate in their community (family, learning environment, school,
community) through showing care and consideration for others.

D588AC8F1BF847B4B322F8C3338120B4.description:
Verbalize or demonstrate their internal debate around whether or not to
break a rule or follow expectations – “I want more crackers, but Mr. Taylor
told me to wait.”

C1981D1CF2194D1AB88B71C61F52325D.description:
Recognize and express frustration or confusion about the differences
between their own families’ expectations and the expectations of other
families for their children – “But Salim’s mom lets him do it!”

5EDAD01A2B8A4A11B821C1C98E06D676.description:
Question a familiar adult’s instructions (“Why do I have to do that?”) while
another child quietly and immediately complies.

30C5983EA3E940B09BBC54909C260380.description:
Expresses frustration when boundaries or expectations are not applied
consistently – “That’s not fair” and “Why can’t I do that too?”

BE287C1A400943FFACF29B608EE006A1.description:
ell a familiar adult when other children aren’t following expectations or
boundaries, such as “Arisa didn’t put the markers away.”

D0AD0AB958554A2A80A7E8C4B33AD285.description:
Inform other children of an expectation they’re not following, for example
“You can’t climb on that!”

9B094E7394164BE2B309166B62A31725.description:
Point out that they are “allowed” to do something or behave a certain way in
another situation – “But Papa says I can!”

1A931F736EB741069501BEE36A0F1129.description:
Begin to make choices that reflect their understanding of fairness and unfairness, as well as the
boundaries and expectations of various situations.

468AFC3573EE42AE80DFE51A8F76D3CC.description:
Children demonstrate an awareness of the ways their choices and actions
may impact the emotional and physical well-being of themselves and others.

461F7642B5AD40CBB896589023A793C9.description: Seek out a familiar adult when they need help to resolve a conflict.

8A630C01CA824EDBB306118429019820.description: Apologize for stepping on another child’s toy.

FDC6E2BBDDC6464DAB8984DDA419C430.description: Share, and ask to share, toys with other children, most of the time.

B3B4DF2C8E3D4E3483FBF270EC2D3EE8.description:
Negotiate with other children to decide who will get the first turn, with adult
support.

BC0DAB3431B24EDC9995F8CC70758842.description:
Tell a familiar adult that they are mad, angry, or sad because another child
took the toy they were playing with.

E2A0214252494F86AB5E74A79EDF3204.description:
With reminders, use “belly breathing,” “bunny breathing,” or other techniques
to manage their own emotions during a conflict.

F2E86E3ABFEE412C8AC0C9BFA7953B8E.description:
Express themselves through words or signs and attempt to explain the
whole story of a particular conflict and why they feel this way.

9317CF95161F4E3AA46EAF6E9B2DAEA3.description:
Express disappointment in others by announcing that they “hate” the other
person.

F66499A40ED846D2927759B5401D9EF0.description: Sometimes take turns or work out other small conflicts with other children.

84EAB3B50928462CBB50D071CDCA5167.description:
Suggest ideas to help resolve conflicts. “I’m playing with this doll, but you
can have that one.”

77E42E6BB9E24110893A81FDDD301DB9.description:
With adult support and reinforcement, listen to another child’s perspective
about a conflict, and work together to come up with ideas for a resolution.

73F1C1D56F3D4F68BC309371AD1E576D.description:
With adult support, identify their big emotions and use breathing techniques
to manage them.

D71354FF1ACF4EDF8B7642B0101CC977.description:
Continue to sometimes express emotions physically, such as knocking down
another child’s block tower because that child wouldn’t let them play.

687A51EE56474612B2D2F724CB434BB8.description:
Seek out a familiar adult to explain their interpretations of what is happening
to cause their emotions. “Billy is being mean to me!”

26977A8C5B0B470981EEAACC290FA241.description:
Use signs, words and phrases that have been modeled for them, when
attempting to resolve conflicts. “I don’t like that.”

0A828C1F3D20400A84DD86F16EC271E3.description: Seek out a familiar adult to help resolve conflicts with other children.

17B7F15599F24E09A6504FEB7B5CC49A.description:
With adult support, practice using words or signs to express their feelings, as
well as the reason for a disagreement or conflict, and their ideas for how to
resolve the issue.

3C8C9213F7B9461D8D2B45D408A0F259.description:
Continue to express emotions physically or in big ways, such as shouting
“No!” when they disagree or don’t want to do something.

441BA9FCFAFD43929FD3EB6F13254995.description: Express disagreement and begin to manage conflict in safe, developmentally appropriate ways.

985590D729434DD5951FF439ACE767EA.description:
Form quick connections with other children who have similar interests or
other common ground.

ACBDEF79B3BA43A8A7BB9A1DA33E3B87.description: Engage in conversation and play with unfamiliar children.

E74DB85153F348538CDA052BF0E49012.description: Ask to play with a new friend again.

AD2AA6559F4842A3B3575C9DCC575A07.description:
Engage in play with unfamiliar children and, with reminders, introduce
themselves.

19B9699189854CD9AC2451AC6C61B700.description: Play with the same few children consistently.

A47B10F5C4AA49F38425D6CB1F887D41.description: Stand on the edge of a group of children they would like to join.

53734770C6434F909E64145571B436AA.description:
Ask other children and familiar adults questions about their families and
home lives.

6DD0B099651A4B0B88B583D1AB6F5F12.description: With support and prompting, introduce themselves to unfamiliar children.

DC37C557153640168C90CBD1623B2039.description:
Spontaneously play alongside or join in play with other children, familiar or
unfamiliar.

9E5E5A8F41E5493B96DCB26008F0A1B3.description:
Engage in pretend play that allows them to explore the roles of favorite
adults.

3E8079C4F41C46D6817ACB8F35A2FD04.description: Show preferences for playing with specific children.

BD9FCB545C59441484D0A856E6E9CA7D.description:
Develop and maintain deep, caring connections, friendships, and other relationships with people of
various cultures, family structures, home languages, racial identities, genders and gender identities, abilities and
disabilities, religious beliefs, and socio-economic classes.

7D4896C91E6842A9B5A506249C44F81F.description: Take turns in conversation with other children.

E62D60AC476F454CBF107C4D1FF8FB87.description:
Use new or additional strategies to enter play with others: suggest something to
do together (“Do you want to play hide and seek?”), offer to share a toy, and join
into existing play (“Can I be the dad in the family?”).

479CB05DBBFB4719A78F8B8D154FF411.description:
Maintain and show enjoyment (smiles, laughter, etc.) of positive interactions with
other children.

B2AD7AB4F6F74830A8339BC28E2C910A.description:
Engage in joint play with others, with increasing intentionality, including making
plans for goals, roles, rules, and expectations of their play–and demonstrate
willingness to include others’ ideas in that planning.

0D39FB59A6F342869184274AA6F69A97.description:
Usually engage with adults by saying hello or goodbye without prompting,
respond to requests or directions from familiar adults, and ask or wait for
permission from a familiar adult if they are not sure about something.

E7164D1221784EC094C12F24475AFE75.description: Usually respond to requests and directions from familiar adults.

64F708231A8C4ABABD4FA4E65A164A6C.description: Engage in longer interactions with both familiar and new adults, with more backand-forth communication.

9930F4E0DD954FE5916BE80FA9B402C6.description:
Begin to show interest in the feelings, likes and dislikes, and general wellbeing of
familiar adults.

A52DBF4AB19B48A8880EA7847C6EBEA3.description:
Show excitement or relief when they can make themselves understood in their
home language.

B657218C74334DD4B6D58EAB88ADD64B.description:
Play cooperatively with others with increasing intentionality, including making
plans with other children about what to play and how (the “rules” of their game or
play, for example).

4DC1C4B1125842A6867C2A1B8E48C257.description:
Engage in longer reciprocal (back-and-forth) interactions with adults to talk about
their experiences. For example, a child might tell a familiar adult, “I went to the
zoo!” and then answer a series of questions about what they saw at the zoo.

8095B04F066C4EDEB0BDFEFBD2723359.description:
Engage in simple cooperative play with others and begin to extend the length of
that play..

3740956FE1254CB8B677388DED5C3FDD.description:
Enter play by making suggestions for other children’s play, such as holding out a
lion toy to children building a zoo and saying, “You could put the lion in that one!”

D331A74E5FA44BC997B91F9C7F1BD52D.description:
Begin engaging in social play by mimicking other children’s play, such as when
other children are playing a running game, begin to run and check if they’ve been
noticed and included.

B5B7D65E93D34EE4AA80E6EE3614460D.description: Communicate their own ideas and ask for help when needed.

6199875851CF44B181ADC280B923508C.description: Show preference for certain children and greet them by name.

A2E6A7D8624B4FC590DF51744D9E266E.description:
Demonstrate an ability to initiate and sustain interactions and communication with others, primarily
in their home language.

B1E9A8A9B19E4709B52A6C8299695622.description: Sit near or lean against a trusted familiar adult.

B3C7A546E1E340ECA3B6216406827044.description: Be eager to share their accomplishments with familiar adults.

911BC9FE68C848B3AAE8AAF3E074124D.description: Show comfort and confidence in expressing themselves to familiar adults.

8A85520C8DF045778E0D96F6A1A4BC85.description: Seek out affection from familiar adults.

0530FE26A9874492B9CD6038E60CBE57.description: Look to or ask adults for comfort and help when needed.

8A22A2E180524F748F743083A46E57E1.description: Glance back at familiar adults to reassure themselves they are not “alone.”

A7C639AE787143B4868492585015A26F.description:
Begin to comfortably interact with an increasing number of significant people
in their lives beyond families and primary caregivers.

4016BFEDC9334921996D8425F9B96EC5.description: Demonstrate healthy attachment to and trust in familiar adults in their lives.

FEBD86AE45484857B2FE5D5560C47DEB.description:
Children interact and communicate to form deep, caring connections, friendships, and
other relationships, and to manage conflict.

68362FF05DCA4C6392D8B4B8AFA26DF7.description:
Recognize and name similarities and differences in their roles, expectations,
and behaviors across different groups and settings.

EC981ABBB801474DA3495741C47D6073.description:
Share stories about being part of a different group than the one they’re
talking to. “When I was at the family reunion…”

BFA495D132584EDEA39CB566076AD2C4.description:
Describe themselves and others using multiple characteristics, including
physical features, talents, culture, and interests.

5A5EE9AA2DC244EC869945B39DF9BD05.description:
Ask for help with something from another child because they recognize it is a
strength of the other child.

0D26122A327B43E3B23A1630033A5F09.description:
Identify themselves as being part of various groups, such as their family,
their neighborhood community, their faith, their school community, as well as
their racial, cultural, linguistic, and gender identities.

DAA99A55E78243E5BCD39898563E08C5.description:
Share a story about a family gathering or otherwise describe their
connections to their family and community.

55A184FA1090453495B0FC3313C1C574.description:
Begin to differentiate themselves more clearly from others. “My dad doesn’t
like to fish, but me and my grandpa do.”

DF4176B7C9244E899C6F9ED3099711EA.description:
Show increased understanding that others have differing interests, thoughts,
beliefs, ideas, feelings, and strengths. “Seanan is fast when she runs!”
“Miguel likes to play in the kitchen.”

7DE3B638FF3B4E3AB27402D54CF2C1D5.description:
Draw pictures of their family or share a special object related to their family
traditions or cultural heritage.

A2A8D09210FC4CA08635ACC3FBEBED6E.description:
Describe their interests, ideas, and likes and dislikes when prompted. For
example, responding with a color name when a familiar adult asks which
colors, they want to play with, or answering a question about their favorite
animal.

958963DC84E94C46B9D516E8660E0ED6.description:
Show increased understanding of their own strengths and interests in
contrast to others’. “I’m a good climber!” and “You like purple, but I like
green.”

CB02EA62963842D692F0B954C1F8AB5E.description:
Demonstrate an understanding that the diverse community of people around them have unique
strengths and experiences to share and should be treated with respect.

6B89792D1DA348DB88E9ADC2BA2FBC44.description:
Notice when there is space in a play area for them to join, and recognize
non-verbal cues, such as the other children looking up and smiling at them
when they approach, as a tool to help them decide if they will ask to join.

BB38B50EB14E4F31889BDC613967E10E.description:
Move a toy or chair out of the path of a child in a wheelchair or walking with
leg braces.

3D252DB7FBB84D6486C93F70AB0B9259.description:
Understand the difference between helpful and hurtful ways to get
something or meet a need.

24999EFB839E45E89FEEDD14B831B64C.description: Talk with other children during snack or mealtime.

5662E6E1237744F2B2E94E407337CCA0.description: Begin to play with friends, for example playing games or building together.

E9F39E6F8F644BDEBCF5E71B0BD3FD39.description: Give a hug to a child who is crying.

C059A04B01CA45B1B0A8BB06B55DF47C.description: Comment on what another child is doing.

DE86DF5A61124EE9A6DA6FD939C771D0.description: Wave someone “toward them” to show them something or seek help.

9346E2A83E3F46898ABBC620641D12D5.description:
Understand facial expressions, vocal tone, and physical tension as cues to
engage or not engage with another person.

C954D8537DD24C7AAE4E46D406EE6852.description: Interact with another child who is playing in the block corner alongside them.

D4B01F6334D248B598232EC568B8902C.description: Recognize and respond to social cues.

977DAF1179B24125BC62FE53FED9E4B7.description:
Accurately recognize and label the emotions of others with increasing
consistency, especially those who are familiar, but also growing to include
strangers and those in stories and other media.

C17D2729563344608B0507C3742F6E4B.description:
Begin to respond to others with empathy – “I’m sorry your grandma couldn’t
come to the lunch today, Jordan. You can sit with me and my grandma!”

A8873CEFD6244E26819931795363873B.description:
Try to predict and identify the cause and/or consequence of others’ emotions
in stories, such as “I think the pigs are scared of the wolf, even though
they’re acting brave when they say, ‘not by the hair of my chinny chin chin.’”
or “I think the wolf is getting angry because the pigs are teasing him.”

6A6051C9637B40F7BD99DCC242465DB5.description:
Notice more subtle expressions of emotion from others, such as recognizing
that a child who is standing outside a group of children playing a game might
be shy or nervous to join in.

8A2FEFBE28FE468383C195051CE7A8DA.description:
Briefly try to help someone who is upset by thinking about that person’s
specific needs. For example, Donetta is sad, and Francesca gets Donetta’s
blanket from her cubby to help or goes to tell an adult that Donetta needs
help.

34E0489C144C4087B4059A3529CF1C4C.description:
Try to predict and identify the cause and/or consequence of others’
emotions, such as “My puppy loves me. He barks and wags his tail and licks
me when I come home!”

DD04D83FB6674B8FAABAB006B63041B1.description:
Notice and label, with increasing accuracy, non-verbal indicators of others’
strong feelings, such as “Jalen’s mad!” when another child stomps their foot.

ACDFB4E1B2FD41A7B76FF470EF79B492.description:
Recognize and respond to other children’s expression of strong feelings,
such as laughing when other children are laughing.

2F031B9FE973460D9CF282E4FC07C6DD.description: Recognize other people’s emotions and respond with care, sensitivity, and later empathy.

67457E51C2D14C5ABA61B412C665F146.description:
Children demonstrate a growing ability to show care and understanding for the way
other people feel, and begin to recognize that people may think, feel, and experience things differently from each
other.

E322CEBA65A4442B974B6196C1EEFE8A.description:
Persist in a challenging task, such as putting together a puzzle and working
through trying a puzzle piece in different spots until it fits.

6E7129F152EE426B9B6164543425E456.description: Notice that a chosen activity is “full” and make a different choice.

2AB5178CEF9142EBA597DBCA3AB7C085.description:
Follow routines with little prompting, such as going to put a coat on when a
familiar adult says, “It’s time to go outside.”

F7C0D7531DB24B4EAE9296947CE1067F.description:
Establish and maintain a familiar goodbye routine for separating from a
family member at school, such as turning around at the door to blow a kiss
goodbye.

3CA810AEE1D74633AFD0BE3C7D8FDBA3.description:
When it is time to transition from learning centers to lunch, help carry the
transition sign around to inform their peers.

2F617B26504C4F958853D11D70BB7C57.description:
When a paint stroke spatters across the paper, look to a familiar adult for
reassurance, and then with that support, incorporate the spatters into the
painting as stars or something else.

5265459A03A94FFAAE0CC4AAB6A8789B.description: With support, retry a difficult task.

CC2F8338457A4B8D9E18F2044D7437E5.description: Manage transitions and follow routines most of the time.

40EF7355AE444D70B7FAB6C2C19C7A1D.description:
Tolerate and enjoy a moderate degree of change, surprises, uncertainty, and
potentially puzzling events.

D123607B23A14111857CF24BAC934520.description: Show understanding that they can run on the playground but not indoors.

5EE34C5C8D1249CEA73BB17FD2F1C56D.description:
Demonstrate an understanding that different settings have different routines
and expectations, such as home and school.

8FFCC2542BFC451793C07EBF80D1B66F.description:
Readily cooperate with routines and tasks when provided with the
opportunity to make choices throughout their day.

9C8BB9EA277244E1A24BE3B5EE0485F1.description: Demonstrate flexibility and an increasing ability to adapt to changes and setbacks.

313AAC02546D4D01A8CF81DCCC3D8FFC.description:
Tell a familiar adult that they are mad, angry, or sad because another child took
the toy they were playing with.

192BA28F14DB4F58836A0D27AC430072.description:
Verbally express what they are feeling using a bigger and more detailed
vocabulary, such as saying, “I’m excited because my mom is taking me to
gymnastics today,” or “I’m proud of me and Josie because we built the tallest
tower.”

E1D9DBEDE5174F7F9250CE3E13CD268B.description:
Use “belly breathing,” “bunny breathing,” or other techniques to manage their
own emotions.

A8A7CB9F3167436EB610E2D69DA454DB.description:
Express themselves through words or signs and attempt to explain the whole
story of why they feel the way they do.

76DA14E859AB4892B194DFA7224F7B40.description: Express disappointment by crumpling a paper they made a mistake on.

CE43CE756AFF4CFC952B07F4FC9DBFA8.description:
With adult support, identify their emotions and use breathing techniques to
manage them.

8E524A9BC4FE4957A475537324F28D4B.description: Say, “That was fun!” or “I don’t like that,” after trying a new activity.

F5CFFB774A6F42FE9DB2ACF4182938EE.description: Verbally express what they are feeling.

80EE5B1F3B5F4660B39D103D888DFD9D.description:
Continue to sometimes express emotions physically, such as knocking down
another child’s block tower because that child wouldn’t let them play.

B26B248629934CF98FE478115826D9AF.description:
Seek out a familiar adult to explain their interpretations of what is happening to
cause their emotions. “Billy is being mean to me!”

D02319D614234ABEA7D87CBE65F9AF55.description: Announce that “He’s funny” when laughing at an adult being silly.

24C56054E3524266B661847D051C09F7.description:
With adult support, practice using words or signs to express their emotions,
needs, and wants.

2E97986D99F641DDB8933C601D2AAFB4.description:
Continue to express emotions physically or in big ways, such as squealing and
twirling in a circle, throwing a toy, or shouting “No!”

344BFAB370E84DE2A31E801A403A1247.description:
Express their emotions freely, and begin to identify and manage those emotions, with support from
familiar adults.

0E234F5D50564C8E85EE30D15999088B.description:
Children recognize the connections between their emotions and reactions and begin to
control their impulses in different situations.

0463CFE12F5B45D7B1A80ECFA2BD6D74.description: May resist repeating experiences they were not previously successful with.

7D6627E4A6EA42E5A9ABB58A5DDC58C9.description: Be reluctant to try new things that may require skills they haven’t mastered.

B0E7C8A441FB46798AEF7ACFCFFCF691.description:
Watch other children play for a moment or two to get a sense of what’s
happening and then go to join in

B251F0868F6E4DE89D68C85714CE137F.description:
With encouragement, introduce themselves to an unfamiliar child and go
play with them.

2FC1BE7C6B854C9E9656575805C05738.description: Join a group of familiar children in playing a new game.

13976BD40C4D421696FAC2F4BA58D6CA.description:
Explore new materials or experiences (like a playground structure) with a
familiar child or adult.

0C16B500394242219B4CAAAEBEA99C1C.description:
With encouragement, “join in” with play by sitting down nearby to play with
the same objects (such as building their own tower near someone else’s
construction).

FAA23ABC35D645B68511586C49F53D5B.description: Watch other children’s play with interest.

AC810674BF2E4B2DAA7C30F01A8E37F9.description: Demonstrate willingness to explore independently and try new things.

7338B95061394E839352C8B73699CD4E.description:
Volunteer to explain what the Spanish words in Abuela mean while a familiar
adult reads the story.

B5742E58E84940ADB01B64DD909D1B23.description: Compare their drawing of a tree to the illustration in a book.

16E541F88FD94FE6B51BF5B216DD6F7E.description:
Point out, while a familiar adult reads the book Abuela to the group, that the
Spanish words in the story are the same language they speak at home with
their family.

330685ACE64F49BBB32F27E2CA243D97.description:
Announce successes and accomplishments, such as “Look, I can climb to
the top of the slide!”

03E773BCB773422D8C7556983542FC46.description: Choose picture books from the library that have main characters who look like them.

A8FE682930D249FA8437D179D659F85A.description:
Demonstrate awareness of and recognize the value of their personal traits, including their strengths
and interests.

939BC22A289244C981131305D8FF9AD0.description: Children recognize and value their own individuality, emotions, and strengths.
